List of Vocabulary

Anticipate - බලාපොරොත්තු වන්න | - To expect or look forward to something happening.

Compelling - ආකර්ෂණීය | - Something that is very interesting or convincing.

Vibrant - සජීවී | - Full of energy, color, or excitement.

Well-versed - සම්පූර්ණ දැනුම් දී ඇති | - Knowledgeable and skilled in a particular area.

Acquainted - දැනුවත් කරන ලද | - Familiar with someone or something.

Narratives - කථා | - Stories or accounts of events or experiences.

Resonate - සහාය වීම | - To have a strong impact or connection with someone emotionally.

Articulate - පැහැදිලි ලෙස ප්‍රකාශ කිරීම | - To express thoughts or ideas clearly and effectively.

Gratifying - සතුටුදායක | - Causing happiness or satisfaction.

Intense - දැඩි | - Very strong or extreme in force or degree.

Budding: උද්යෝගි / නවක; - Beginning to develop or grow, especially in a promising way.

Embrace: ආදරය කළ හැකි / අල්ලා ගැනීම; - To accept or support something willingly; to hug someone.

Obvious: පැහැදිලි / සාමාන්‍ය; - Easily seen or understood; clear and apparent.

Strike: තරමට කඩවා / පහර දීම; - To hit or make contact with something forcefully.

Metaphor: ආසන්න රූපය; - A figure of speech that describes something by referring to it as something else, suggesting a similarity.

Terminology: පදවිදිය; - The specific words or phrases used in a particular field of study or profession.

Leveraging: ප්‍රයෝජනයක් ලබා ගැනීම; - Using something to maximum advantage.

Inadvertently: නොසිතාගනිමින්; - Unintentionally or accidentally.

Differentiator: විශේෂකය; - A factor or characteristic that distinguishes one thing from another.

Distinguishing: වෙන් කිරීමට / භේද කිරීමට; - Serving to identify or differentiate; characteristic.

Toppings: මැදිරි රසකැදැල්ල | Items added on top of food, like cheese or vegetables, to enhance flavor.

Truncated: කඩාකප්පල් වූ | Cut short or reduced in length.

Novel clicks: නව ක්ලික් | New or unique interactions or engagements, often in digital contexts.

Drastic: දැවැන්ත | Extreme or severe in effect or action.

Conventions: සාම්ප්‍රදායික | Accepted rules, practices, or standards in a particular field.

Contrast: විපරිතතාව | The difference between two or more things, highlighting their dissimilarities.

Relay: නැවත යැවීම | To pass on information or signals from one person or place to another.

Fountain: සෙරෙප්පු | A structure that sends water up into the air, often for decoration.

Monotonous: වර්ණමය රහිත | Boring and repetitive; lacking in variety.

Resembles: ප්‍රමාණවත් | To look like or be similar to someone or something else.

Density: ඝනත්වය | The amount of mass in a given volume of a substance.

Caution: සතුට | Care taken to avoid danger or mistakes; being careful.

Causation: හේතු ප්‍රතිපලය | The relationship between cause and effect; when one thing causes another to happen.

Implies: ඇතුළත් කරයි | To suggest or indicate something without directly stating it.

Correlation: සම්බන්ධතා | A mutual relationship or connection between two or more things.

Inverse: විරුද්ධ | Opposite in effect or nature; a reversal of something.

Lightning Strikes: අස්වැන්න | A natural electrical discharge of very short duration and high voltage between a cloud and the ground.

Consumption: පරිභෝජනය | The act of using up resources or goods.

Tempting: ප්‍රේමය | Attractive or appealing, often in a way that encourages someone to want to do something.

Conclude: නිගමනය | To bring something to an end or to finish; to reach a decision or opinion.

Stakes: භාජන - The risks or importance of a situation or decision.

Pellagra: පෙලාග්‍රා - A disease caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3).

Symptoms: ලක්ෂණ - Signs or indications of a condition or disease.

Dizziness: මුවාවීම - A feeling of lightheadedness or spinning.

Sores: වෙදකම - Painful spots or wounds on the body.

Diarrhea: ඉදිරිපස - Frequent loose or watery bowel movements.

Niacin: නයසින් - A type of vitamin B3 important for health.

Aid: උදව් - Help or assistance in doing something.

Suppose: විශ්වාස කරන්න - To think or believe something is true or possible.

Clues: සංකේත - Hints or pieces of information that help solve a problem or mystery.

Critically - ප්‍රබල ලෙස: In a way that expresses careful judgment or opinion.

Frostbite - හිම ගැටීම: Injury caused to body parts from extreme cold.

Sledding - ස්ලෙඩ් කිරීම: Riding on a sled down a hill, often for fun.

Concerning - සම්බන්ධයෙන්: Regarding or relating to a particular topic.

Entail - ඇතුළත් කරයි: To involve or require something as a necessary part.

Corresponding - සමාන / අනුපිළිවෙල: Matching or related to something else.

Avid - දැඩි / කාලාබාධක: Having a strong interest or enthusiasm for something.

Steadily - මනා ලෙස: In a constant and regular manner.

Clustering - කලාප කිරීම: Grouping similar items or data together.

Cues - සැඟවීම්: Signals or hints that guide behavior or actions.

Pertaining: සම්බන්ධීකරණය - Relating to something; associated with.

Quarterly: හතුරු කාලය - Occurring every three months.

Plotted: කුටියෙන් තැබීම - Marked or represented on a graph or chart.

Adequate: ප්‍රමාණවත් - Sufficient or enough for a particular purpose.

Obscured: ගුඩාකාරය - Hidden or made difficult to see.

Diagonal: විශාලකාර - Slanting direction from one corner to another in a shape.

Dimensional: මානයන් - Related to the measurements of length, width, and height.

Symmetry: සමාන්තරතාව - Balanced or harmonious arrangement of parts.

Hue: වර්ණය - A shade or tint of a color.

Intensity: කාරුණිකභාවය - The strength or brightness of something, often related to color or light.

Dull: කුඩු - Not bright or lively; lacking interest or excitement.

Tints: වර්ණාංකිත - Slight shades or colors added to something.

Play out: ක්‍රීඩා කිරීම - To happen or develop over time; to unfold.

Traces: සොයාගන්න - Signs or evidence of something that was present or happened.

Interactivity: අන්තර්ක්‍රියාව - The ability to communicate or respond to one another, often in a digital context.

Sparingly: කුඩා ප්‍රමාණයෙන් - Using something in limited amounts; not wastefully.

A fine line: සුළු සීමාව - A very small difference between two things that are often confused.

Delicate: ඉතා සුළු - Fragile or easily broken; requiring careful handling.

Provoking: කුණු කාරී - Causing a strong reaction, often by challenging or stimulating thoughts.

Appeal: ආකර්ෂණය - The quality of being attractive or interesting.

Thorough: සම්පූර්ණ - Done carefully and completely.

Evenly: සමාන ලෙස - In a way that is balanced or the same on both sides.

Mimic: අනුකරණය කරන්න - To imitate or copy someone or something.

Focal: මධ්‍යස්ථානගත - Relating to the center or main point of interest.

Unified: එක්කෙරුණු - Made into a whole or brought together as one.

Cohesive: සම්බන්ධිත - Forming a united whole; working well together.

Sophisticated: නව්‍ය - Complex or advanced in design or development.

Stresses: ආවේනිකතා - Emphasizes or highlights something important.

Inexplicably: පැහැදිලි නොවන ලෙස - In a way that cannot be explained or understood.

Overrated: ඉතා උද්දීපිත - Considered better or more important than it really is.

Treasures: බෝන - Valuable items or possessions.

Breeds: වර්ග - Types or kinds of animals or plants.

Compiled: එකතු කළ - Gathered and put together.

Overlooked: අමතක කළ - Failed to notice or pay attention to.

Perceived: හැඟීමක් ඇතිවූ - Became aware of or understood something.

Silhouettes: සිල්හොට් - Dark shapes or outlines of objects against a lighter background.

Inset: ඇතුළත් කොටු - A small picture or map placed within a larger one.

Continents: මහද්වීප - Large land masses on Earth.

Stacks up: කුඩු කිරීම් - Piles or accumulates over time.

Enlightened: ප්‍රබුද - Gained knowledge or insight; informed.

Pharmaceutical: ඖෂධ - Related to drugs or medicines.

Dramatic: වාසනාවන්ත - Sudden and exciting; theatrical.

Empathizing: හැඟීම් අනුකම්පාව - Understanding and sharing the feelings of others.

Integrating: එක්කරන - Combining parts to create a whole.

Embrace: ගුරුතුමා - To accept or support willingly.

Impaired: අහිතකර - Weakened or damaged in some way.

Deficiencies: අඩුවීම් - Lacks or shortages of something needed.

Utilities: උපයෝගීතා - Services or products that are useful, like water and electricity.

Besides: තව දුටු - In addition to; apart from.

Discretionary: ඡේදනයක් - Based on individual judgment; optional.

Debt: ණය - Money that is owed to someone.

Volatility: ආර්ථික වාසිය - The degree of variation in price or value.

Tri-City: ත්‍රි නගරය - A region consisting of three cities.

Elementary: පදනම - Basic or simple in nature.

Guardrails: ආරක්ෂක තීරුවල් - Safety barriers to prevent accidents.

Elegant: සුන්දර - Graceful and stylish in appearance.

Components: කොටස් - Parts that make up a whole.

Acronyms: යුගල පාඨ - Abbreviations formed from the initial letters of words.

Abbreviations: අක්ෂර කෙටුම්පත - Shortened forms of words or phrases.

Sarcasm: විරෝධාත්මක විවේචනය - The use of irony to mock or convey contempt.

Beside: පැත්තේ - Next to or at the side of something.

Axes: අක්ෂ - Plural of axis; lines about which an object rotates.

Callouts: කැඳවුම් - Labels or annotations that highlight specific parts of a diagram.

Varies: වෙනස් විය - To change or be different.

Exclusively: විශේෂිත ලෙස - Only for a specific group or purpose.

Legends: පුරාණ කතා - Traditional stories or historical figures.

Braille: බ්‍රෙයිල් - A tactile writing system used by people who are visually impaired.

Cognitive: සංවේදී - Related to mental processes like thinking and understanding.

Foreground: ඉදිරිපස - The part of a scene that is nearest to the viewer.

Solely: පමණක් - Only or exclusively; without others.

Textures: අතුරු පාරිසරික - The feel or appearance of a surface or material.

Cater: ආහාර සැපයීම - To provide food and services for an event.

Inclusive: සභාපතික - Open to all; not excluding any group.

Mock up: ආදර්ශයක් - A model or prototype used for demonstration purposes.

Hone: මනාකිරිම - To improve or perfect a skill or quality.

Gauge: මැනීම - To measure or assess something.

Enclosure: වටකරගත් ස්ථානය - A space that is closed off or surrounded.

Proximity: ආසන්නත්වය - Being near or close to something.

Emphasis: විශේෂයෙන් සලකුණක් දක්වීම - Special importance or focus on something.

Diminishes: අඩුවීම - To make or become less.

Art form: කලාවක් - A particular kind of creative activity.

Bigfoot: බිග්ෆුට් - A legendary creature said to live in forests.

Sightings: දැකීම - Instances of seeing something unusual.

Unleash: නිදහස් කර ගැනීම - To release or let something loose.

Deficiencies: අඩුපාඩු - Lacking important elements.

Diverging: වෙනස් වීම - Moving in different directions from a point.

Toggle: මාරු කිරීම - To switch between options or states.

Admire: ගෞරව කිරීම - To respect or look up to someone or something.

Longitude: දීර්ඝාංශ - Distance east or west of the prime meridian.

Latitude: අක්ෂාංශ - Distance north or south of the equator.

Whisker: කප්පු - Long, stiff hairs on animals’ faces.

Emissions: ප්‍රතික්‍රියාව - Gases or particles released into the air.

Proportional: සාපේක්ෂ - Matching in size or amount to something else.

Emitted: නිකුත් කරන ලද - Released or sent out.

Depicting: පැහැදිලිව පෙන්වීම - Showing or representing something in a picture or words.

Magnitude: ප්‍රබලතාව - The size or extent of something.

Brace: සජ්ජකරනවා - To prepare or support firmly.

Enhancements: වැඩිදියුණුකම් - Improvements made to something.

Company’s C-suite: කර්මාන්තයේ ප්‍රධාන මට්ටමේ - Senior executives leading a company.

Entails: ඇතුළත් කරයි - Involves or includes something as part.

Optimize: කාර්යක්ෂම කරගන්නවා - Make as effective or functional as possible.

Data-ink ratio: දත්ත-හිස් කලාප අනුපාතය - Amount of ink used to present data compared to design elements.

Orientation: දිශානුදේශනය - Position or direction of something.

Deceptive: වංචාකාරී - Intended to mislead or trick.

Binned: කාණ්ඩ කරයි - Grouped or sorted into categories.

Disguising: වෙස්පත් කිරීම - Hiding the real appearance or nature.

Sum up: එකතු කර ගන්නවා - To summarize or total something.

Cumulative: එකතු වූ - Increasing by adding to previous amounts.

Generosity: දායකත්වය - Willingness to give or share freely.

Steepest: බොහෝ පහත හෝ ඉහළ යාම - Having the most rapid rise or fall.

Incline: නැඹුරුව - Slope or slant of a surface.

Juggling: එකම වේලාවට වැඩ කිහිපයක් කළයුතු තත්වය - Managing several tasks at once.

Beige: කහපාට - A light brown color.

captivated - ඇලවුන / Drawn in strongly.

motion - චලනය / Movement or action.

persuade - කැමති කරන්න / To convince.

attributes - ගුණාංග / Qualities or characteristics.

resonates - සමඟ ගැලපේ / Matches or connects well.

narrative - කතාන්දර / Story or description.

tune out - අහනේ නැති කරන්න / Ignore or block out.

skim - ඉක්මනින් කියවන්න / Read quickly.

proportions - අනුපාත / Ratios or relative sizes.

elegant - අලංකාර / Graceful or stylish.

derived - සාරය ගන්නා / Taken or obtained from something.

punchline - හඬුන හැටියට / Main part of a joke.

pace - වේගය / Speed or rate.

archaeologists - පුරාවිද්‍යාඥයන් / Scientists who study ancient things.

artifacts - පුරාණ නිර්මාණ: Historical objects made by humans.

imply - නිරූපණය කිරීම: Suggest without saying directly

cholera outbreak - කොලරාවාද රෝගය: Spread of cholera disease.

ill humors - අසාධාරණ ගුණාංග: Bad moods or attitudes.

contaminated - අපවිත‍්‍ර: Made impure or polluted.

gross water - අලෝකසම නිරෝධිත ජලය: Dirty or unpleasant water.

dismantle - කඩාගන්න: Take apart.

epidemiology - වසංගත විද්‍යාව: Study of disease spread.

beneath - යටතේ: Underneath or below.

distilled - ස්පෂ්ට පිරිසිදු කරන ලද: Purified or refined.

doodle - කුඩා චිත්‍ර: Simple, quick drawing.

sift through - තෝරගන්න - Go through to find something.

tweak - සිසිල් බවට පෙරලන්න - Make a small change.

cohesive - එකතුව ඇති - Sticking together well.

evenly - සමාන්තරව - Spread out equally.

stale - පනස් නාස්ති - Not fresh.

state - ප්‍රකාශ කරන්න - Describe clearly.

curated views - පරිපාලනය කරපු දසුන් - Selected and organized views.

alleviates - නිරාක්ව කරන්න - Makes less severe.

chaos - කෙලවෙන්න - Complete disorder.

familiarize - හුරු කරන්න - Make oneself aware of.

tailored - විශේෂ - Specially designed.

compelling - අක්කෙනුත් ඉල්ලූ - Powerful and interesting.

persuasive - පිලිගන්න ලියවිල්ල - Convincing others.

gross domestic product - ජාතික ආර්ථික වාස්තුව - Total economic value of a country.

outliers - විෂම විෂය - Very different points or things.

clutter - අවුල් - Mess or disorganized space.

tactics - අභ්‍යාස - Specific strategies.

gradient - හැඩයක් - A gradual change.

spectrum - රිද්ම - A range or set of things.

at your disposal - අතේ තිබ්බිම - Available for use.

emitted - එපානයකින් පැවරීම - Released or sent out.

preliminary - මුලික - First step or early stage.

cap off the process - කටයුත්තේ අවසානය - Finish up the steps.

pertinent - අදාල - Relevant or related.

appealing - ආකර්ෂණීය - Attractive or interesting.

cram - ඉස්සරනවා - To fill or pack tightly, often with studying.

imposter - වංචකයා - A person pretending to be someone else.

syndrome - රෝග ලක්ෂණ - A set of symptoms often occurring together.

exposure - අනාවරණය - Being subjected to something.

blow this up - විශාල කරයි - To make something bigger or more intense.

pep talk - හුරුබුහුටියක් - A motivational speech to encourage someone.

anticipate - ඉදිරියට සිද්ධියක් බලාපොරොත්තු වීම; expect something to happen in the future.

weave - දාම්පත් එකට ගෙතීම; to combine materials or ideas together.

guacamole - ඇවොකාඩෝ අමුතුම ආහාරයකි; a Mexican avocado-based dip.

surge - අතිශය ඉහළට නැඟීම; a sudden, powerful upward movement.

rubric - අනුපාත රීති පද්ධතිය; a set of criteria for assessment.

retains - තබා ගැනීම; to keep or hold onto something.

contextualize - පසුබැසීම සකස් කිරීම; to place in a particular setting for understanding.

subsequent - පසුව සිදු වීම; coming after something else.

reinforces - ශක්තිමත් කිරීම; to make something stronger.

essentially - යථාර්ථයෙන්ම; in its most basic or important form.

coherent - සංයුක්ත සහිත; logical and well-organized.

elevate - උස කරනු; to lift or raise something.

fundamental - මූලිකම; basic and essential.

glazing over - මනස අනේකම් දියුණු වීම; becoming less interested or focused.

pet peeve - අකමැත්තක් හෝ පිළිගන්නේ නැති දෙයක්; a minor annoyance.

eyesore - දුෂ්ටදසුන; something that looks unpleasant.

ally - මිත්‍රයෙක්; a friend or supporter.

nodding - හිස කෙලෙසීම; moving the head up and down to show agreement.

poke - ඇනික්කර ගැනීම; to jab or prod with a finger.

lend - ණය දීම; to give something temporarily.

articulate - පැහැදිලිව ප්‍රකාශ කිරීම; to express something clearly.

Critique - විවේචනය; a detailed analysis or review.

orientation - පූර්වදැනුම් වැඩසටහන; introduction to a new environment.

caveats - අනතුරු ඇඟවීම; warnings or limitations.

decipher - අර්ථය හඳුනාගැනීම; to understand or figure out.

comprehend - අර්ථය අවබෝධ කර ගැනීම; to understand fully.

gaze - බැල්මෙන් බලා සිටීම; to look steadily at something.

conclude - අවසානයේ පසුවට පත් කර ගැනීම; to reach a decision or end.

uneven - සමාන නොවීම; not smooth or equal.

disseminated - පතුරුවා හැරීම; spread or distribute widely.

demographic - ජනගහනය අධ්‍යයනය; study of population details.

underutilized - අඩු ප්‍රයෝජනයට ලක් වීම; not used enough.

bogged down - ගැටලු වලට බලා සිටීම; to get stuck or slowed.

sporadically - කාලෙකට කල් ක්‍රමයෙන් සිදු වීම; happening irregularly.

coefficient - ගණන කුලකය; number multiplying a variable.

infer - අනාවරණය කර ගැනීම; to guess based on evidence.

sustained - නිරන්තරයෙන් පවත්වා ගැනීම; kept going continuously.

causal - හේතුවෙන් වන; relating to cause.

adrenaline - සක්‍රීය කටයුතු වන හෝර්මෝනය; hormone for action or energy.

a good rule of thumb - මනා පුරුද්දක්; general practical guideline.

mitigate - අඩු කිරීම; to make less severe.

sink - යට වීම; to go down or submerge.

rush - කඩිසරකම් දරා ගැනීම; to hurry.

breadcrumbs - පොඩි හෝ සැලසුම් වටා දැක්වීම; small helpful steps.

skim - ඉක්මනින් බලා යෑම; read quickly for main ideas.

norms - සාමාන්‍ය ව්‍යාපාර ක්‍රමවේද; accepted standards.

consolidation - එකතු කර තහවුරු කිරීම; combining to make stronger.

candid - විවෘතව කතා කිරීම; honest and open.

sequel - අඛණ්ඩ අවස්ථාව; next part or continuation.

integral - අනිවාර්ය කොටසක්; essential part.

jargon - විශේෂ භාෂාව; special language.

tailored - පරිස්සමෙන් සැකසූ; made to fit specific needs.

incorporate - ඇතුළත් කිරීම; include as part of something.

complement - එකිනෙකට ගැලපීම; something that goes well with something else.

pauses - නතර වීම; short breaks or stops.

monologue - එකම පුද්ගලයෙකුගේ කථාව; one person’s speech or talk.

foster - වැඩිදියුණු කරනවා; to encourage or develop something.

reinforces - තවත් ශක්තිමත් කරනවා; strengthens or supports more.

underpins - මූලිකත්වය සපයනවා; supports as a base or foundation.

crafted - සලකුණු කර හදන ලද; carefully made or designed.

accelerator - වේගය වැඩි කරන උපකරණය; device to increase speed.

constructive - ප්‍රයෝජනවත්; useful and helpful.

forethought - කලින් සිතුවීම; thinking ahead or planning.

tempting - ඉතා කැමැත්තක් ඇති; hard to resist or very appealing.

curse - අවජාතක කථාවක්; a harmful or offensive word or phrase.

tap your toes - ඔබේ පැත්තෙට අත් පහරදීම; move toes up and down in rhythm.

derail - මඟ හරිනවා; to disrupt or go off course.

supplementary - අමතර; something extra or additional.

intimidating - භීතිජනක; making someone feel scared or nervous.

revise - නැවත සැලකීම; to review or change something.

monetary - මුදල් සම්බන්ධ; related to money.

pinpoint - නිවැරදිව තීරණය කරනවා; to identify exactly.

accounted - හේතු දක්වන ලද; explained or taken into account.

autonomous - ස්වයංපාලිත; able to act independently.

heartburn - අසනීපයක් ඇති කරයි; a burning feeling in the chest.

concerned - ප්‍රයෝජනයක් ඇති; worried or interested.

reputable - ගෞරවනීය; having a good reputation.

credentials - සුදුසුකම්; qualifications or proof of ability.

extensive - විශාල; large in amount or range.

tactics - ක්‍රමවේද; strategies or planned actions.

bouncing around - එකින් එක විවිධ අදහස්; moving from one idea to another.

appealing - ආකර්ශනීය; attractive or interesting.

pursuit - අනුගමනය කිරීම; chasing or following something.

Visualize data

Module 1. 7 hours to complete

11 videos Total 50 minutes

Transcript

MCQs

Introduction to communicating data insights •3 minutes

  • Hey there, it's great to see how far you've come in this Google Data Analytics certificate.
  • First of, I want to say congrats on your achievement.
  • Second, welcome to your next course.
  • It's all about the art of data storytelling through visualization.
  • As a data analyst, you can do all the necessary work of planning, collecting, cleaning, and analysis.
  • But you also need to show stakeholders what your data means in a compelling way using visuals.
  • We're here to show you how that's done.
  • With my experience as Director of Analytics at Google, I hope I'll be a pretty good guide.
  • My name's Kevin, and I'll be your instructor for this course.
  • This part of your training is particularly meaningful to me because I love data storytelling.
  • I can't think of anything in today's business world that's more vibrant, more exciting, and more rewarding.
  • With the amount of data we have around us, data analytics plays a key role in pretty much every part of business.
  • In my opinion, there isn't a skill that's more important to you as an analyst than being able to effectively communicate the stories you want to covered to stakeholders.
  • Stakeholders usually lack the time, access to data, or expertise needed to find those stories by themselves.
  • That's why we'll focus on visualizing data to help you better share Data Stories.
  • Which means we're now at the share phase of the data analysis process.
  • We'll start with the basic concepts of visualization and why visualizing your analysis is such an important part of Data Analytics.
  • From there, we'll discuss how to plan for and start building effective visualizations that are inclusive, accessible, and consider the audience first.
  • Afterwards, we'll explore one possible tool you can use for data visualization, Tableau.
  • Tableau helps us create visualizations from our analysis so that we can share our findings more effectively.
  • We'll show you how data visualizations, including visual dashboards, can help bring your data to life.
  • We'll also explore how you can use visualizations in your presentations and slide shows to continue telling a story with data.
  • We'll discuss the art and science behind effective presentations.
  • Finally, you'll learn how to anticipate and answer questions from stakeholders and respond to their feedback.
  • Throughout the course, I'll guide you through what I think is the most exciting part of the data analysis process.
  • By the end, you'll have everything you need to plan, create, and present an effective and compelling data visualization.
  • Now that we've gotten to know each other little, it's time to get down to business.
  • Coming up, we'll talk a bit about the history of data visualization and why visualizations mattered so much today.
  • We'll also discuss the methods for using imagery effectively and what you can do to make the most out of your visuals.
  • See you there.

Who is the instructor for the course on data storytelling through visualization?

  • A. Kevin, Director of Analytics at Google
  • B. John, Data Scientist at Microsoft
  • C. Sarah, Senior Data Analyst at IBM
  • D. David, Business Analyst at Amazon
  • Answer: A. Kevin, Director of Analytics at Google

What is the primary focus of this course?

  • A. Learning programming languages for data analysis
  • B. Mastering the art of data storytelling through visualization
  • C. Understanding advanced statistical methods
  • D. Developing database management skills
  • Answer: B. Mastering the art of data storytelling through visualization

At which phase of the data analysis process does this course primarily focus?

  • A. Planning
  • B. Collecting
  • C. Cleaning
  • D. Sharing
  • Answer: D. Sharing

  • A. To reduce the size of datasets
  • B. To make the data collection process easier
  • C. To communicate data stories effectively to stakeholders
  • D. To perform statistical analysis
  • Answer: C. To communicate data stories effectively to stakeholders

  • A. Python
  • B. R
  • C. Tableau
  • D. Excel
  • Answer: C. Tableau

  • A. Programming
  • B. Data storytelling and visualization
  • C. Statistical analysis
  • D. Data cleaning
  • Answer: B. Data storytelling and visualization

  • B. Building data models
  • C. The art and science behind effective presentations
  • D. Software development techniques
  • Answer: C. The art and science behind effective presentations

  • A. The history of programming languages
  • B. The history of data visualization
  • C. Database management systems
  • D. Cloud computing technologies
  • Answer: B. The history of data visualization

What is one of the key benefits of using visual dashboards in data storytelling?

  • A. They reduce the time required for data collection
  • B. They make data cleaning more efficient
  • C. They help bring the data to life
  • D. They automate data analysis
  • Answer: C. They help bring the data to life

  • A. Create and manage databases
  • B. Plan, create, and present effective data visualizations
  • C. Perform advanced statistical analysis
  • D. Write complex code for data processing
  • Answer: B. Plan, create, and present effective data visualizations

Kevin: The power's in the data viz •2 minutes

  • Data Analytics is the collection and analysis and then use of data to tell stories, using charts and visualizations, so that businesses can make better decisions.
  • So I've always loved numbers and have always enjoyed math and calculus and those sorts of things.
  • So data came really easy to me.
  • I was working at a consultancy before and using lots of numbers, and I enjoyed it for sure.
  • But it wasn't until I worked at an advertising agency where I saw the creative expression of numbers and how data could drive that creativity.
  • That it really all fell into place for me and I realized that doing analytics in a marketing and in an advertising setting was exactly what I wanted to do.
  • And I found that I just really enjoyed when we put those two things together.
  • I think the visuals that come out of data analysis and data analytics are really beautiful, but what is even more interesting for me are the stories behind them.
  • If you look at a big block of text or a big block of numbers, those stories are in there, but they really have to be found.
  • And so it takes certain skill to pull those things out.
  • And I find that skill, that analysis really exciting and interesting.
  • But it ultimately then ends in a beautiful visualization, which I find very gratifying.
  • There are great data visualization thinkers, and you see these visuals all over the place.
  • You can find inspiration from looking at news outlets today and seeing the visuals that they present and how they tell stories that way.
  • Visualizations have become so important that you can find them everywhere, and you could take great inspiration from that.
  • But I also take inspiration from unlikely sources like photography and art and others and seeing how composition is created, how color is used.
  • I think that's really important.
  • And I try hard to bring those sorts of elements and those sorts of influences into the visualizations I create.
  • So I know this course is pretty intense.
  • We're throwing a lot at you.
  • Your brain is probably overloaded.
  • You're probably fried.
  • Just stick with it.
  • It is all going to start to piece together and make sense.
  • The biggest thing that I think you can think of is just how important these skills really are.
  • This is the new way of doing business, involving data, using the analytics tools and techniques that we're talking about to make decisions.
  • So there's a great big reward waiting for you at the end of this course.
  • I'm Kevin.
  • I'm director of analytics here at Google. [SOUND]

Why data visualization matters •6 minutes

  • Welcome back, future data analyst.
  • As a budding analyst, you'll be exposed to a lot of data.
  • People learn and absorb data in so many different ways, and one of the most effective ways that this can happen is through visualization.
  • Data visualization is the graphic representation and presentation of data.
  • In reality, it's just putting information into an image to make it easier for other people to understand.
  • If you've ever looked at any kind of map, whether it's paper or online, then you know exactly how helpful visuals could be.
  • Data visualizations are definitely having a moment right now.
  • Online we are surrounded by images that show information in all kinds of ways, but the history of data visualization goes back way further than the Web.
  • Visualizing data began long ago with maps, which are the visual representation of geographic data.
  • This map of the known world is from 1502.
  • Map makers continued to improve their visualizations as new lands were charted.
  • New data was collected about those locations, and new methods for visualizing the data were created.
  • Scientists and mathematicians began to truly embrace the idea of arranging data visually in the 1700s and 1800s.
  • This bar graph is from 1821 and it doesn't look too different from bar graphs that we see today.
  • But since the beginning of the digital age of data analytics in the 1990s, the scope and reach of visualizations have grown along with the data they graphically represent.
  • As we keep learning how to more efficiently communicate with visuals, the quality of our insights continue to grow too.
  • Today we can quantify human behavior through data, and we've learned to use computers to collect, analyze and visualize that data.
  • As an analyst in today's world, you'll probably split your time with data visuals in two ways: looking at visuals in order to understand and draw conclusions about data or creating visuals from raw data to tell a story.
  • Either way, it's always good to keep in mind that data visualizations will be your key to success.
  • This is especially true once you reach the point where you're ready to present the results of your data analysis to an audience.
  • Getting people to understand your vision and thought process can feel challenging.
  • But a well-made data visualization has the power to change people's minds.
  • Plus, it can help someone who doesn't have the same technical background or experience as you form their own opinions.
  • So here's a quick rule for creating a visualization.
  • Your audience should know exactly what they're looking at within the first five seconds of seeing it.
  • Basically, this means the visual should be clear and easy to follow.
  • In the five seconds after that, your audience should understand the conclusion your visualization is making.
  • Even if they aren't totally familiar with the research you've been doing.
  • They might not agree with your conclusion, and that's okay.
  • You can always use their feedback to adjust your visualization and go back to the data to do further analysis.
  • So now let's talk about what we have to do to create a visualization that's understandable, effective and, most importantly, convincing.
  • Let's start from the beginning.
  • Data visualizations are a helpful tool for fitting a lot of information into a small space.
  • To do this, you first need to structure and organize your thoughts.
  • Think about your objectives and the conclusions you've reached after sorting through data.
  • Then think about the patterns you've noticed in the data, the things that surprised you and, of course, how all of this fits together into your analysis.
  • Identifying the key elements of your findings help set the stage for how you should organize your presentation.
  • Check out this data visualization made by David McCandless, a well-known data journalist.
  • This graphic includes four key elements: the information or data, the story, the goal and the visual form.
  • It's arranged in a four-part Venn diagram, which tells us that all four elements are needed for a successful visualization.
  • So far, you've learned a lot about the data used in visualizations.
  • That's important because it's a key building block for your visualization.
  • The story or concept adds meaning to the data and makes it interesting.
  • We'll talk more about the importance of data storytelling later, but for now, just remember that the story and the data combined provide an outline of what you're trying to show.
  • The goal or function makes the data both useful and usable, and the visual form creates both beauty and structure.
  • With just two elements, you can create a rough sketch of a visual.
  • This could work if you're at an early stage, but won't give you a complete visualization because you'd be missing other key elements.
  • Even using three elements gets you closer, but you're not quite finished.
  • For example, if you combine information, goal, and visual form without any story, your visual will probably look fine, but it won't be interesting.
  • On their own, each element has value, but visualizations only become truly powerful and effective when you combine all four elements in a way that makes sense.
  • And when you think about all of these elements together, you can create something meaningful for your audience.
  • At Google I make sure to develop visualizations to tell stories about data that include all four of these elements, and I can tell you that each element is a key to a visualization success.
  • That's why it's so important for you as the analyst to pay close attention to each element as we move forward.
  • Other people might not know or understand the exact steps you took to come to the conclusions you've made, but that shouldn't stop them from understanding your reasoning.
  • Basically, an effective data visualization should lead viewers to reach the same conclusion you did, but much more quickly.
  • Because of the age we live in, we're constantly being shown different ways to view and absorb information.
  • This means that you've already seen lots of visuals you can reference as you design your own visualizations.
  • You have the power to tell convincing stories that could change opinions and shift mindsets.
  • That's pretty cool.
  • But you also have the responsibility to pay attention to the perspectives of others as you create these stories.
  • So it's important to always keep that in mind.
  • Coming up, we'll start drawing connections between data and images to create a strong foundation for your visual masterpieces.
  • I can't wait to get started.
  1. What is data visualization?
  • A) A method of collecting data from various sources
  • B) The graphic representation and presentation of data
  • C) The process of analyzing raw data
  • D) A way to store data securely
    Answer: B) The graphic representation and presentation of data
  1. How long should it take for an audience to understand what they are looking at in a data visualization?
  • A) 2 seconds
  • B) 5 seconds
  • C) 10 seconds
  • D) 15 seconds
    Answer: B) 5 seconds
  1. What are the four key elements necessary for a successful data visualization, according to David McCandless?
  • A) Information, story, visual form, and context
  • B) Data, analysis, presentation, and feedback
  • C) Information, story, goal, and visual form
  • D) Data collection, storage, analysis, and presentation
    Answer: C) Information, story, goal, and visual form
  1. Why is storytelling important in data visualization?
  • A) It allows for more data to be displayed on the screen
  • B) It adds meaning to the data and makes it interesting
  • C) It helps in storing data securely
  • D) It improves the resolution of visual graphics
    Answer: B) It adds meaning to the data and makes it interesting
  1. How did visualizing data begin historically?
  • A) With bar graphs in the 1800s
  • B) During the digital age in the 1990s
  • C) With maps as a visual representation of geographic data
  • D) Through the invention of computers
    Answer: C) With maps as a visual representation of geographic data
  1. What should be done if the audience does not agree with the conclusion presented in a data visualization?
  • A) Ignore their feedback
  • B) Adjust the visualization based on their feedback and perform further analysis
  • C) Change the data to support your conclusion
  • D) Discard the visualization entirely
    Answer: B) Adjust the visualization based on their feedback and perform further analysis
  1. What is one of the responsibilities of a data analyst when creating data visualizations?
  • A) To ensure that their visuals are complex and technical
  • B) To pay attention to the perspectives of others
  • C) To limit the data being visualized
  • D) To use as many colors as possible for visual appeal
    Answer: B) To pay attention to the perspectives of others
  1. According to the transcript, why have data visualizations become more important in recent times?
  • A) Because traditional data analysis techniques are becoming obsolete
  • B) Due to the increase in the amount of data generated in the digital age
  • C) Because paper maps are no longer used
  • D) Because data visualization tools are easier to use now
    Answer: B) Due to the increase in the amount of data generated in the digital age
  1. What is the main purpose of data visualization, as discussed in the transcript?
  • A) To make information more accessible and understandable to others
  • B) To store data more securely in digital formats
  • C) To ensure data is analyzed automatically without human intervention
  • D) To replace traditional data presentation methods like reports
    Answer: A) To make information more accessible and understandable to others
  1. What does the combination of information, goal, and visual form without a story result in?
  • A) A complete and effective data visualization
  • B) A visualization that may look fine but lacks interest
  • C) A confusing and disorganized visualization
  • D) A perfect data analysis report
    Answer: B) A visualization that may look fine but lacks interest

Connect images with data •6 minutes

Question

A bar graph has an x-axis and a y-axis. Describe the difference between the two. Select all that apply.

The x-axis is a vertical line. The y-axis is a horizontal line

The x-axis usually has a scale of values for variables. The y-axis is used to represent categories, time periods, or other variables

The x-axis is used to represent categories, time periods, or other variables. The y-axis usually has a scale of values for variables

The x-axis is a horizontal line. The y-axis is a vertical line

Correct

The x-axis is a horizontal line used to represent categories, time periods, or other variables. The y-axis is a vertical line that usually has a scale of values for variables.

  • Hello again.
  • Earlier we talked about why data visualizations are so important to both analysts and stakeholders.
  • Now we'll discuss the connections you can make between data and images in your visualizations.
  • Visual communication of data is important to those using the data to help make decisions.
  • To better understand the connection between data and images, let's talk about some examples of data visualizations and how they can communicate data effectively.
  • You maybe come across lots of these in your daily life.
  • We'll explore them a little bit more here.
  • A good place to start is a bar graph.
  • Bar graphs use size contrast to compare two or more values.
  • The horizontal line of a bar graph usually placed at the bottom, is called the x-axis, and bar graphs with vertical bars, the x-axis is used to represent categories, time periods, or other variables.
  • The vertical line of a bar graph usually placed to the left is called the y-axis.
  • The y-axis usually has a scale of values for the variables.
  • In this example, the time of day is compared to someone's level of motivation throughout the whole workday.
  • Bar graphs are a great way to clarify trends.
  • Here, it's clear this person's motivation is low at the beginning of the day and gets higher and higher by the end of the workday.
  • This type of visualization makes it very easy to identify patterns.
  • Another example is a line graph.
  • Line graphs are a type of visualization that can help your audience understand shifts or changes in your data.
  • They're usually used to track changes through a period of time, but they can be paired with other factors too. 
  • In this line graph, we're using two lines to compare the popularity of cats and dogs over a period of time.
  • With two different line colors, we can immediately tell that dogs are more popular than cats.
  • We'll talk more about using colors and patterns to make visualizations more accessible to audiences later too.
  • Even as a line moves up and down, there's a general trend upwards and the line for dogs always stays higher than the line for cats.
  • Now let's check out another visualization you'll probably recognize.
  • Say hello to the pie chart.
  • Pie charts show how much each part of something makes up the whole.
  • This pie chart shows us all the activities that make up someone's day.
  • Half of it's spent working, which is shown by the amount of space that the blue section takes up.
  • From a quick scan, you can easily tell which activities make up a good chunk of the day in this pie chart and which ones take up less time.
  • Earlier, we learned how maps help organize data geographically.
  • The great thing about maps is they can hold a lot of location-based information and they're easy for your audience to interpret.  
  • This example shows survey data about people's happiness in Europe.
  • The borderlines are well-defined and the colors added make it even easier to tell the countries apart.
  • Understanding the data represented here, which we'll come back to again later, can happen pretty quickly.
  • So data visualization is an excellent tool for making the connection between an image and the information it represents, but it can sometimes be misleading.
  • One way visualizations can be manipulated is with scaling and proportions.
  • Think of a pie chart.
  • Pie charts show proportions and percentages between categories.
  • Each part of the circle or pi should reflect its percentage to the whole, which is equal to 100 percent.
  • So if you want to visualize your sales analysis to show the percentage of your company sales that come from online transactions, you could use a pie chart.
  • The size of each slice would be the percentage of total sales that it represents.
  • So if your online sales accounted for 60 percent, the slice would be 60 percent of the whole pie.
  • Now here's a misleading pie chart.
  • It's supposed to show opinions about pizza toppings, but each slice or segment represents more than one option.
  • They all add up to well over 100 percent.
  • There is lots of ingredients listed below the image that are not even included in the visual data.
  • All of the segments are the same size, even though they're supposed to be showing different values.
  • If a visualization looks confusing then it probably is confusing.
  • Let's explore another example where the size of the graphic components comes into play.
  • This time with a bar chart.
  • In a truncated bar chart like this one, the values on the y-axis don't start at zero.
  • The data points start at 9,100 and at intervals of 100.
  • This makes it seem like the data, let's say, it's for novel clicks per day on different website links, is fairly wide-ranging.
  • In this view, website E seems to clearly receive way more clicks than website D, which receives more clicks than website C and so on.
  • While the graph is clear and the elements are easy to understand, the way the data is presented is misleading.
  • Let's try to fix this by changing the graph's y-axis, so that it starts at zero instead.
  • Now, the difference between the website clicks per day don't look nearly as drastic.
  • By making the y-axis start at zero, we're changing the visual proportions to be more accurate and more honest.
  • Some platforms always start their y-axis at zero, but other programs like spreadsheets might not fix the y-axis.
  • So it's important to keep this in mind when creating visualizations.
  • By following the conventions of data analysis, you'll be able to avoid misleading visualizations.
  • You always want your visualization to be clear and easy to understand, but never at the expense of communicating ideas that are true to the data.
  • So we've talked about some effective data-driven visualizations like bar graphs, line graphs, and pie charts, and when to use them.
  • On top of that, we've discussed some things to avoid in your visualizations to keep them from being misleading.
  • Coming up, we'll check out how to make those visualizations reach your target audience.
  • See you then.

1. What is the primary purpose of data visualizations?
a. To replace written reports entirely
b. To entertain the audience with graphics
c. To help analysts and stakeholders make decisions
d. To confuse the viewer with complex images

Answer: c. To help analysts and stakeholders make decisions

2. What do bar graphs use to compare values?
a. Different shapes
b. Size contrast
c. Colors only
d. Animations

Answer: b. Size contrast

3. In a bar graph, what does the x-axis usually represent?
a. A scale of values
b. The total number of items
c. Categories, time periods, or other variables
d. Proportions between categories

Answer: c. Categories, time periods, or other variables

4. What type of data is a line graph most commonly used to display?
a. Geographic information
b. Shifts or changes over time
c. Comparisons between parts of a whole
d. Categorical data

Answer: b. Shifts or changes over time

5. What is the purpose of using different line colors in a line graph?
a. To make the graph more visually appealing
b. To show different data sets for comparison
c. To distract the audience from the data
d. To emphasize only one set of data

Answer: b. To show different data sets for comparison

6. What do pie charts show?
a. The relationship between two variables
b. How much each part contributes to the whole
c. Changes over time
d. Data trends and shifts

Answer: b. How much each part contributes to the whole

7. Which of the following can make a pie chart misleading?
a. Including all relevant categories
b. Using colors to differentiate segments
c. Displaying more than one category in each slice
d. Showing percentages that add up to 100%

Answer: c. Displaying more than one category in each slice

8. What is a common issue with truncated bar charts?
a. They use too many colors
b. They make differences between data values look smaller than they are
c. They may not start the y-axis at zero, which can exaggerate differences
d. They are difficult to understand

Answer: c. They may not start the y-axis at zero, which can exaggerate differences

9. What is the recommended starting point for the y-axis in most bar charts?
a. The average value
b. Zero
c. The smallest data point
d. Any value that makes the data look better

Answer: b. Zero

10. Why is it important to avoid misleading visualizations?
a. To ensure the graphics are complex enough
b. To avoid distracting the audience
c. To communicate ideas that are true to the data
d. To make the data seem more significant

Answer: c. To communicate ideas that are true to the data

A recipe for a powerful visualization •5 minutes

  • Hey, there.
  • You're back and ready to learn how to create powerful data visualizations.
  • Coming up, we'll explore how to take our findings and turn them into compelling visuals.
  • Earlier, we discussed the relationship between data and images.
  • Now we'll build on that to explore what visualizations can reveal to your audience and how to make your graphics as effective as possible.
  • One of your biggest considerations when creating a data visualization is where you'd like your audience to focus.
  • Showing too much can be distracting and leave your audience confused.
  • In some cases, restricting data can be a good thing.
  • On the other hand, showing too little can make your visualization unclear and less meaningful.
  • As a general rule, as long as it's not misleading, you should visually represent only the data that your audience needs in order to understand your findings.
  • Now let's talk about what you can show with visualizations.
  • Change over time is a big one.
  • If your analysis involves how the data has changed over a certain period, which could be days, weeks, months, or years.
  • You can set your visualization to show only the time period relevant to your objective.
  • This visualization shows the search interests in news story topics like environment and science and social issues.
  • The viz is set up to show how the search entries change day to day.
  • The bubbles represent the most popular topic on each day in a given part of the US.
  • As new stories come up, the data changes to reflect the topic of those stories.
  • If we wanted the data for weekly or monthly news cycles, we change the interactive feature to show changes by week or month.
  • Another situation is when you need to show how your data is distributed.
  • A histogram resembles a bar graph, but it's a chart that shows how often data values fall into certain ranges.
  • This histogram shows a lot of data and how it's distributed on a narrow range from a negative one to a positive one.
  • Each bin or bucket, as the bar is called, contains a certain number of values that fall into one small part of the range. 
  • If you don't need to show that much data, other histograms would be more effective, like this one about the length of dinosaurs.
  • Here the bins or buckets of data values are segmented.
  • You can show each value that falls into each part of the range.
  • If your data needs to be ranked, like when ordering the number of responses to survey questions.
  • You should first think about what you want to highlight in your visualization.
  • Bar charts with horizontal bars effectively show data that are ranked, with bars arranged in ascending or descending order.
  • A bar chart should always be ranked by value, unless there's a natural order to the data like age or time, for example.
  • This simple bar chart shows metals like gold and platinum ranked by density. 
  • An audience would be able to clearly see the ranking and quickly determine which metals had the highest density, even if this database included a lot more metals.
  • Correlation charts can show relationships among data, but they should be used with caution because they might lead viewers to think that the data shows causation.
  • Causation or a cause-effect relationship occurs when an action directly leads to an outcome.
  • Correlation and causation are often mixed up because humans like to find patterns even when they don't exist.
  • If two variables look like they're associated in some way, we might assume that one is dependent on the other.
  • That implies causation, even if the variables are completely independent.
  • If we put that data into a visualization, then it would be misleading.
  • But correlation charts that do show causation can be effective.
  • For example, this correlation chart has one line of data showing the average traffic for Google searches on Tuesdays in Brazil.
  • The other lines for a specific date of search traffic, June 15th.
  • The data is automatically correlated because both lines are representing the same basic information.
  • But the chart also shows one big difference.
  • When a football match or soccer match for Americans began on June 15th, the search traffic showed a significant drop.
  • This implies causation.
  • Football is a very popular and important sport for Brazilians, and the data in this chart verifies that.
  • We've now talked about time series charts, histograms, ranked bar charts, and correlation charts.
  • Each of these charts can visualize a different type of analysis.
  • Your business objective and audience will help figure out which of these common visualizations to choose.
  • Or you may want to check some other kinds of visualizations out there.
  • There are also glossary visualizations that you'll be able to reference later.
  • That wraps up our lesson on creating visualizations.
  • Coming up next, we'll add some more layers to your planning and execution of visuals.
  • Hang on tight.
  1. What is one of the biggest considerations when creating a data visualization?
  • A) Using bright colors
  • B) Adding as much data as possible
  • C) Deciding where the audience should focus
  • D) Using complex visual effects

Answer: C) Deciding where the audience should focus

  1. When can restricting data in a visualization be a good thing?
  • A) When it helps prevent confusion and distraction
  • B) When you want to make the visualization look simple
  • C) When you want to include as much data as possible
  • D) When you are working with time-series data

Answer: A) When it helps prevent confusion and distraction

  1. What type of data is best suited for a time-series visualization?
  • A) Data about the distribution of values
  • B) Data that changes over a certain period
  • C) Data that shows correlation
  • D) Data ranked in a particular order

Answer: B) Data that changes over a certain period

  1. What does a histogram represent?
  • A) The relationship between two variables
  • B) How data values are distributed across certain ranges
  • C) The ranking of data points in ascending or descending order
  • D) The total number of values in a dataset

Answer: B) How data values are distributed across certain ranges

  1. When creating a ranked bar chart, how should the bars be arranged?
  • A) Randomly
  • B) By value, unless there is a natural order
  • C) By color
  • D) In alphabetical order

Answer: B) By value, unless there is a natural order

  1. What is the difference between correlation and causation?
  • A) Correlation implies a cause-effect relationship, while causation does not
  • B) Causation occurs when one action directly leads to an outcome, while correlation does not imply causation
  • C) Correlation always means causation
  • D) Causation only exists in scientific studies

Answer: B) Causation occurs when one action directly leads to an outcome, while correlation does not imply causation

  1. Why should correlation charts be used with caution?
  • A) Because they are difficult to create
  • B) Because they often require advanced software
  • C) Because they might lead viewers to think that correlation implies causation
  • D) Because they only work for time-series data

Answer: C) Because they might lead viewers to think that correlation implies causation

  1. In the example given about search traffic in Brazil, what was implied as the cause of a significant drop in search traffic?
  • A) A natural disaster
  • B) A football (soccer) match
  • C) A public holiday
  • D) A technical glitch

Answer: B) A football (soccer) match

  1. Which of the following is NOT mentioned as a common type of data visualization?
  • A) Histogram
  • B) Time-series chart
  • C) Pie chart
  • D) Correlation chart

Answer: C) Pie chart

  1. What should guide the choice of visualization type for a specific analysis?
  • A) The latest design trends
  • B) The type of software being used
  • C) The business objective and audience
  • D) The number of data points available

           Answer: C) The business objective and audience

Dynamic visualizations •3 minutes

  • Hey, great to see you again.
  • So far we've shown that there's lots of choices you'll make as a data analyst when creating visualizations.
  • Each of your choices should help make sure that your visuals are meaningful and effective.
  • Another choice you'll need to make is whether you want your visualizations to be static or dynamic.
  • Static visualizations do not change over time unless they're edited.
  • They can be useful when you want to control your data and your data story.
  • Any visualization printed on paper is automatically static.
  • Charts and graphs created in spreadsheets are often static too.
  • For example, the owner of this spreadsheet might have to change the data in order for the visualization to update.
  • Now, dynamic visualizations are interactive or change over time.
  • The interactive nature of these graphics means that users have some control over what they see.
  • This can be helpful if stakeholders want to adjust what they're able to view.
  • Let's check out a visualization about happiness that we've created in Tableau.
  • Tableau is a business intelligence and analytics platform that helps people see, understand, and make decisions with data.
  • Visualizations in Tableau are automatically interactive.
  • We'll go into the dashboard to see how the happiness score has changed from 2015 to 2017.
  • We can check this out in our 12th slide, yearly happiness changes.
  • On the left are the country level changes in happiness score.
  • The countries are sorted by largest increase to largest decrease.
  • On the right, there's a map with overall happiness scores.
  • The color scale moves from blue for the countries with the highest happiness score, to red for those with the lowest.
  • If you look below the map, you'll notice a year to view slider where people can choose which year's happiness scores to display on the map.
  • It's currently set for 2016, but if someone wants to know the scores for 2015 or 2017, they can adjust the slider.
  • They could then make note of how the color-coding and score labels change from year to year.
  • Other dynamic visualizations upload new data automatically.
  • These bar graphs continually update data by the minute and second.
  • Other data visuals can do the same by day, week or month.
  • If you need to, you can show trends in real-time.
  • Having an interactive visualization can be useful for both you and the audience you share it with.
  • But it's good to remember that the more power you give the user, the less control you have over the story you want the data to tell.
  • It's something to keep in mind as you learn how to create your own visualizations.
  • You want to find the right balance between interactivity and control.
  • Something else to consider is, a choice between using a static or dynamic visualization.
  • This will usually depend on the data you're visualizing, the audience you're presenting to, and how you're giving your presentation.
  • Now that we've made some decisions about what kind of data vis we want to create, we can start thinking about the design, which is exactly where we're going to start talking about next time.
  • See you there.

What is one of the key choices a data analyst needs to make when creating visualizations?
a) Whether to use 3D graphics
b) Whether to use bright or dark colors
c) Whether the visualizations should be static or dynamic
d) Whether to include animations in the visualizations
Answer: c) Whether the visualizations should be static or dynamic

Which of the following is true about static visualizations?
a) They automatically update as new data is added.
b) They can be easily changed by the user without editing the data.
c) They remain unchanged over time unless manually edited.
d) They require an internet connection to function.
Answer: c) They remain unchanged over time unless manually edited.

How can dynamic visualizations be beneficial to stakeholders?
a) They require less data cleaning and preparation.
b) They allow stakeholders to adjust what they are able to view.
c) They can be printed and distributed easily.
d) They are always simpler to understand than static visualizations.
Answer: b) They allow stakeholders to adjust what they are able to view.

What tool was used in the transcript to create a visualization about happiness?
a) Microsoft Excel
b) Google Data Studio
c) Tableau
d) Power BI
Answer: c) Tableau

How are countries represented in the Tableau visualization mentioned in the transcript?
a) By bar graphs showing happiness trends over decades.
b) Using a map with color scales indicating happiness scores.
c) With pie charts showing happiness distribution.
d) Through scatter plots comparing various social indicators.
Answer: b) Using a map with color scales indicating happiness scores.

In the Tableau visualization example, what feature allows users to change the displayed year's happiness score?
a) A color legend
b) A drop-down menu
c) A year-to-view slider
d) A filter by region button
Answer: c) A year-to-view slider

What is one potential drawback of giving users more control over dynamic visualizations?
a) Users may find it difficult to interpret the data.
b) It may reduce the control over the data story being told.
c) The visualizations are more likely to become outdated quickly.
d) It can limit the types of data that can be displayed.
Answer: b) It may reduce the control over the data story being told.

What factors should be considered when choosing between static and dynamic visualizations?
a) The budget for creating the visualizations
b) The complexity of the visualization software
c) The data being visualized, the audience, and the presentation method
d) The amount of time available to create the visualizations
Answer: c) The data being visualized, the audience, and the presentation method.

Which statement is true about other dynamic visualizations besides the Tableau example?
a) They require manual updates to reflect new data.
b) They can only show data changes on a yearly basis.
c) They can automatically update data in real-time or at set intervals.
d) They are always less engaging than static visualizations.
Answer: c) They can automatically update data in real-time or at set intervals.

What is the next topic mentioned in the transcript that will be discussed?
a) Data cleaning
b) Design of data visualizations
c) Advanced data analysis techniques
d) Building data dashboards
Answer: b) Design of data visualizations

Elements of art •4 minutes

Question

In data visualizations, colors are described by their hue, intensity, and value. The hue is the color. Intensity is how bright or dull the color is. What is the value?

The color’s distinctness from other colors

The color’s lightness or darkness

The highlights within the color

The mood set by the color

Correct

The value is how light or dark the color is in a visualization. Value indicates how much light is being reflected.

  • Hello, and welcome back.
  • You probably didn't think you'd be learning about art in a data analytics course, but that's exactly what we're going to do.
  • Both data analysts and artists use elements of art in their work.
  • We'll introduce those elements to you here, and we'll show you how to apply them to visualizations later.
  • The elements we'll check out are line, shape, color, space and movement.
  • Now, these aren't the only elements to consider, but these particular ones can add value to your data viz by making them more visually effective and compelling.
  • Lines and visualizations can be curved or straight, thick or thin, vertical, horizontal, or diagonal. 
  • They can add visual form to your data and help build a structure for your visualization.
  • These charts show some of the variety that lines can bring to your data viz.
  • The combo chart shows two different types of lines, both providing a graphic for the data.
  • The line chart does the same, but uses curved lines instead.
  • Shapes are also known for their variety.
  • Shapes and visualizations should always be two-dimensional.
  • This is because three-dimensional objects in a visualization can complicate the visual and confuse the audience.
  • Shapes are also a great way to add eye-catching contrast, especially size contrast to your data story.
  • This circle used for a pie chart lets someone quickly understand the data in a familiar format.
  • Shapes with symmetry are usually more familiar to people, so there's less work for the audience to do when viewing symmetrical data viz.
  • But the asymmetrical shapes in this map are still instantly recognizable as countries.
  • It's good to note that the data you're sharing with your audience will usually inform the types of shapes you want to use in your data viz.
  • Next, we have colors, and colors are, well, colors.
  • Of course, in the eyes of artists and analysts, colors can be much more complex.
  • Colors can be described by their hue, intensity, and value.
  • The hue of a color is basically its name, red, green, blue and so on.
  • Intensity is how bright or dull a color is, and finally, there's value.
  • The value is how light or dark the colors are in a visualization.
  • In more scientific terms value indicates how much light is being reflected.
  • Dark values with some black added are called shades of color, like these shades of green.
  • Light values with white added are called tints, like these tints of blue.
  • In this map, there are shades and tints of gray.
  • The value of these colors help us understand the population data in the map and varying the color's value can be a very effective way to draw our audience's attention to specific areas.
  • Space is the area between, around and in the objects.
  • There should always be space in data visualizations, just not too much or too little.
  • For example, the space between the bars of a bar graph like this one should be smaller than the width of the bars themselves.
  • This will draw the viewer's attention to the bar and the data it represents instead of the empty space.
  • Finally, there's movement.
  • Movement is used to create a sense of flow or action in a visualization.
  • One of my favorite examples is the data viz, the Wealth and Health of Nations.
  • This viz showcases a correlation between the financial health and physical health of nations.
  • It traces these elements over time so you can see how the two correlated effects play out.
  • The movement pulls in data from the 1800s all the way up until recently.
  • The interactivity allows for a greater volume of data to be displayed and we'll reveal multiple stories from the same data visualization.
  • Remember, this is something that should be used sparingly.
  • There's a fine line between attracting attention and distracting the audience.
  • A static image lets you control all elements of the story you want to tell.
  • When you start incorporating movement and interactivity, the story is controlled by whoever is controlling the interactivity, whether that's you or possibly your audience if you've turned control over to them.
  • We'll discuss this delicate balance later on in the course.
  • When you bring many of these art elements together in a visualization like this one about sea levels, it can be beautiful and provoking.
  • It proves that there's a place for creative expression in data analytics.
  • Coming up, we'll continue exploring ways to add meaningful creative expression to your data viz.
  • Bye for now.
  1. What are the elements of art mentioned in the course that can be applied to data visualizations?
  • A. Line, texture, pattern, and value
  • B. Line, shape, color, space, and movement
  • C. Line, shadow, contrast, and motion
  • D. Shape, value, texture, and symmetry
    Answer: B. Line, shape, color, space, and movement
  1. Which of the following statements is true about lines in data visualizations?
  • A. Lines should always be straight and thin for clarity.
  • B. Lines can only be used to represent data in line charts.
  • C. Lines can be curved, straight, thick, or thin, and help build a structure for visualizations.
  • D. Vertical lines are the only type of lines useful for visualizations.
    Answer: C. Lines can be curved, straight, thick, or thin, and help build a structure for visualizations.
  1. Why should shapes in visualizations always be two-dimensional?
  • A. To ensure they look realistic and familiar.
  • B. Because three-dimensional shapes can complicate the visual and confuse the audience.
  • C. To make the visual appear more colorful.
  • D. To save space in the visualization.
    Answer: B. Because three-dimensional shapes can complicate the visual and confuse the audience.
  1. How can color be effectively used in data visualizations?
  • A. By using only shades of one color to make the visualization simple.
  • B. By varying the hue, intensity, and value of the color to draw attention.
  • C. By using the same intensity for all colors.
  • D. By avoiding tints and shades in order to maintain a uniform appearance.
    Answer: B. By varying the hue, intensity, and value of the color to draw attention.
  1. What does 'value' refer to in the context of color in data visualizations?
  • A. The name of the color, such as red, green, or blue.
  • B. The brightness or dullness of the color.
  • C. The lightness or darkness of the color.
  • D. The amount of color used in a visualization.
    Answer: C. The lightness or darkness of the color.
  1. In terms of space, what is an important consideration for data visualizations?
  • A. There should be no space between the objects to make the visual compact.
  • B. The space between elements should be larger than the elements themselves.
  • C. The space between elements should be smaller than the width of the elements to focus on the data.
  • D. Space is not a significant factor in data visualizations.
    Answer: C. The space between elements should be smaller than the width of the elements to focus on the data.
  1. What is a potential drawback of incorporating movement in a data visualization?
  • A. It always makes the visualization less attractive.
  • B. It can make the data harder to understand if used excessively.
  • C. It prevents the viewer from interacting with the visualization.
  • D. It eliminates the need for color and shape.
    Answer: B. It can make the data harder to understand if used excessively.
  1. What is a benefit of using symmetrical shapes in visualizations?
  • A. They require more effort for the audience to understand.
  • B. They are more familiar to people and make the data easier to interpret.
  • C. They always provide more detail compared to asymmetrical shapes.
  • D. They are better suited for three-dimensional visualizations.
    Answer: B. They are more familiar to people and make the data easier to interpret.
  1. Which visualization example was mentioned to illustrate the use of movement?
  • A. A bar graph showing population data
  • B. A pie chart displaying market share
  • C. The "Wealth and Health of Nations" visualization
  • D. A line chart comparing sales over time
    Answer: C. The "Wealth and Health of Nations" visualization
  1. What does the transcript suggest about the balance between static and interactive visualizations?
  • A. Static visualizations should be avoided as much as possible.
  • B. Interactive visualizations allow the creator to control all aspects of the story.
  • C. Both static and interactive visualizations have their uses, and the choice depends on who controls the interactivity.
  • D. Static visualizations are more engaging than interactive ones.
    Answer: C. Both static and interactive visualizations have their uses, and the choice depends on who controls the interactivity.

Data visualization impact •5 minutes

Question

Data visualizations have three essential elements: clear meaning, a sophisticated use of contrast, and refined execution. What is refined execution?

Clearly communicating insights

Providing visual context

Deep attention to detail

Separating the most important data from the rest

Correct

Refined execution means paying deep attention to detail. This is done by using visual elements such as lines, shapes, colors, value, space, and movement.

  • Welcome back, let's jump in.
  • Hopefully by now we've developed a clear picture of data viz.
  • We've explored everything from design principles to the types of charts you can use in your visualizations.
  • Choosing the right visualization for your data findings can often come down to one question.
  • Which one will make it easiest for the user to understand the point you're trying to make?
  • No matter how complex your analysis is, your audience will only care about what's in front of them and how easy they can understand it.
  • As you complete your analysis, you'll have to decide which visualization serve your needs and your audiences needs for each task.
  • For example, if you want to show a comparison of the different age groups of visitors to a website, a line graph with a line for each age group, plus one for total users would work well.
  • Let's say you want to highlight the differences among the age groups to compare them or directly, for that you might use a positive negative bar chart like this.
  • We've touched on this before, but let's make some more connections between the data you'll have after analysis and the visualizations you'll want to use for different cases.
  • We'll start with some charts.
  • You've worked with some of these before and will cover more about charts with more examples later.
  • You'll also discover that the best charts to suit your purposes might depend on the needs of your industry, and company, and the stakeholders who will be in your audience. 
  • For comparing data over time we showed you how line graphs could be effective.
  • Like in this one bar graphs and stacked bar graphs, along with area charts, can also be good ways to visualize how data changes over time.
  • By the way, there's a lot of charts out there, we'll give you as much information as possible about as many as we can.
  • But doing your own research or practicing using them in visualizations will also be helpful.
  • Okay, when you're comparing distinct objects like in our example about mobile versus computer usage, ordered bar, and group bar graphs, and ordered column charts are useful.
  • Then there's charts that show parts of a whole.
  • This is known as data composition, and it's achieved by combining the individual parts of a visualization and displaying them together as a whole.
  • Stack bars, donuts, stacked areas, pie charts and tree maps can do all this.
  • Now to show relationships in your data, you might want to use scatterplot and bubble charts, column/line charts and heatmaps.
  • Let's revisit the happiness data vis to show you an example of this.
  • Each of these scatterplots show the relationship between a country's happiness score and one of the factors that contributes to that score.
  • So the health versus happiness scatterplot shows a strong relationship between the life expectancy of people living in a country and how happy those people are.
  • Basically, as life expectancy increases, so does their happiness score.
  • Speaking of happiness, a successful data visualization results in a happy audience.
  • So it's important to understand how your audience is viewing your data visualizations, since they should always be top of mind.
  • And it all starts in the brain, when processing information our brains try to find patterns and rely on visual context.
  • As data analysts, we can use our understanding of the human visual system to produce better visuals.
  • When we create visualizations, we can do so in a way that helps the audience process the information and helps them remember what they're seeing.
  • Visual journalists Dona Wong proposes that effective visuals, like the database we've been discussing here have three essential elements.
  • The first is clear meaning, good visualizations clearly communicate their intended insight.
  • The second is a sophisticated use of contrast, which helps separate the most important data from the rest using visual context that our brains naturally look for.
  • The third essential element for effective visuals is refined execution.
  • Visuals with refined execution include deep attention to detail, using visual elements like lines, shapes, colors, value, space and movement.
  • In other words, the elements of art that we talked about earlier.
  • The first rule in most businesses is to satisfy the customer, it's no different with data analytics.
  • While your customers will probably be managers and other stakeholders, you should always think of them first when creating data visualizations.
  • Think about the five second rule we called out earlier.
  • If you make your data viz easy to look at and understand quickly, then you have done your job and then you'll be satisfied just like your customers.
  • Coming up we'll talk about design, thinking and data visualizations.
  • See you soon.

1. What is the main factor to consider when choosing the right visualization for your data?

  • A) The type of software used to create the visualization
  • B) The complexity of the data
  • C) The ease with which the user can understand the visualization
  • D) The number of colors used in the visualization

Answer: C) The ease with which the user can understand the visualization

2. When showing a comparison of different age groups of website visitors, which visualization would be most suitable?

  • A) Pie chart
  • B) Line graph with a line for each age group
  • C) Scatterplot
  • D) Tree map

Answer: B) Line graph with a line for each age group

3. What type of chart is useful for comparing distinct objects, such as mobile versus computer usage?

  • A) Stacked bar chart
  • B) Scatterplot
  • C) Ordered bar or grouped bar graph
  • D) Donut chart

Answer: C) Ordered bar or grouped bar graph

4. Which type of visualization is commonly used to show data composition?

  • A) Heatmap
  • B) Scatterplot
  • C) Pie chart
  • D) Line graph

Answer: C) Pie chart

5. When showing the relationship between variables, such as health versus happiness, which chart type would be appropriate?

  • A) Line graph
  • B) Scatterplot
  • C) Stacked area chart
  • D) Tree map

Answer: B) Scatterplot

6. According to Dona Wong, which of the following is NOT one of the three essential elements for effective visualizations?

  • A) Clear meaning
  • B) High number of data points
  • C) Sophisticated use of contrast
  • D) Refined execution

Answer: B) High number of data points

7. What does the "five-second rule" in data visualization refer to?

  • A) Making the visualization interactive within five seconds
  • B) Ensuring the audience can understand the visualization quickly
  • C) Limiting the visualization to five key data points
  • D) Using only five colors in the chart

Answer: B) Ensuring the audience can understand the visualization quickly

8. Why is it important to consider the human visual system when creating data visualizations?

  • A) Because it can help produce visuals that aid in processing and remembering information
  • B) Because visualizations must always be in black and white
  • C) Because colors are the most important element in data visualizations
  • D) Because charts should be as complex as possible for maximum impact

Answer: A) Because it can help produce visuals that aid in processing and remembering information

9. What role does "contrast" play in creating effective visualizations?

  • A) It makes the visualization more colorful
